sections.1_story: Imagine you are quickly sorting exam answer sheets into piles based on roll numbers divisible by 2, 3, or 5. Divisibility rules help you instantly decide which numbers belong to which group, saving time in exams and real life.

ğŸ§® Divisible by 4: Last two digits divisible by 4
ğŸ§® Divisible by 5: Last digit is 0 or 5
ğŸ§® Divisible by 6: Divisible by both 2 and 3
ğŸ§® Divisible by 8: Last three digits divisible by 8
ğŸ§® Divisible by 9: Sum of digits divisible by 9
ğŸ§® Divisible by 10: Last digit is 0
ğŸ§® Divisible by 11: Difference of sum of alternate digits is 0 or 11
ğŸ§® Divisible by 12: Divisible by both 3 and 4
ğŸ§® Divisible by 7: Double last digit, subtract from rest; result divisible by 7
ğŸ§® Divisible by 13: Add 4 times last digit to rest; result divisible by 13
ğŸ§® Divisible by 15: Divisible by both 3 and 5
ğŸ§® Divisible by 25: Last two digits 00, 25, 50, or 75

4_micro_examples: Is 156 divisible by 12? Yes (divisible by 3 and 4)

5_exam_examples.question: Is 12345 divisible by 5?
solution_steps: If last digit is 0 or 5, number is divisible by 5.

5_exam_examples.question: Is 1750 divisible by 25?
solution_steps: If last two digits are 00, 25, 50, or 75, divisible by 25.
